title: Troops aid homeless in chinese quake area
author: Ap
text: PEKING (AP) _ Troops today began building makeshift shelters for some 16,000 people left homeless by a major earthquake that jolted western China, while rescue workers distributed burial cloth, food and other essentials, officials said         The state seismological bureau in Peking said the official toll from the Friday disaster remained at 60 dead and 125 injured. However, local authorities in Xinjiang Uighur autonomous region reported 63 deaths.         Thirteen medical teams, including army medics, worked to prevent the outbreak of infectious diseases among survivors.         The quake measured 7.4 on the Richter scale, signifying a jolt capable of widespread, heavy damage. It occurred in a sparsely settled, mainly agricultural region near the Soviet border, inhabited mostly by Moslem Uighur herdsmen and other ethnic minorities.         People's Liberation Army units brought in 29 large tents and built makeshift sheds for those forced to live in the open.         The Kashgar prefecture Communist Party promised to rebuild all the 3,391 homes destroyed by the quake within one month, in time for the Oct. 1 celebration of the 30th anniversary of Xinjiang autonomous region.         The family of each dead person was issued 26 feet of white cloth for funeral services. The local custom is to wrap the body in white before burial.         The Xinjiang Seismological Bureau recorded 631 aftershocks, measuring from 1.0 to 5.1 on the Richter scale.
